channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Belarus Clears Main Border Crossing With Poland
item.description: The camps where thousands had massed in recent days sat empty on Thursday, as some migrants took shelter in a Belarus government warehouse. Their fate was uncertain as European leaders were skeptical of the Belarusian leader’s moves to ease the crisis.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants walking from the Polish border to a warehouse shelter on Thursday in Belarus.

item.title: Furor Over Peng Shuai's #Metoo Accusation Challenges China
item.description: The tennis world is outraged over the latest twist in a star player’s complaint of assault and abrupt disappearance from public life.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Steven Lee Myers
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.media:description: Peng Shuai at the Australian Open in Melbourne in January 2020.

item.title: India's Toxic Air Pollution Prompts Supreme Court to Act
item.description: Schools and factories close. India’s Supreme Court blasts the government’s do-nothing response. But Delhi residents continue to suffer from the bad air.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: New Delhi as it was engulfed in heavy smog last week.

item.title: The Women Bringing Sex Ed to the Arab World
item.description: Activists are using social media to do what Arab countries have failed to do: teach women about their bodies. They are aiming for nothing less than a cultural awakening.
item.dc:creator: Mona El-Naggar and Sara Aridi
item.media:credit: Heba Khamis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nour Emam, also known by the web handle “motherbeing,” hosts one of the leading platforms for sex education in the Arab world.

item.title: Fury in Kashmir After Deadly Police Raid at Shopping Complex
item.description: Saying that the men killed in a gun battle were separatist militants or “terrorist supporters,” security forces refused to return the bodies to their families.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Relatives and neighbors of men who were killed in a clash this week with the police in a shopping center in Srinagar, Kashmir.

item.title: Who Does Afghanistan's Soccer Team Represent Now?
item.description: Afghanistan’s national soccer team played a rare match this week. But what, and whom, does the team represent?
item.dc:creator: James Montague and Bradley Secker
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Must This Covid Swab Go So Far Up Your Nose?
item.description: Some testers gently swab the front of your nostril and send you on your way. Others dig deep, bringing the pain. What’s the gold standard?
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Covid-19 test with a deep nasal swab in Seoul, South Korea.

item.title: Intractable African Crises Flare as Biden’s Top Diplomat Visits Kenya
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken hoped to ease the turmoil engulfing Sudan and Ethiopia in his first trip to sub-Saharan Africa. Both worsened on his first full day.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken speaking in Nairobi, Kenya, on Wednesday.

item.title: Risk for Leader of Belarus: Migrants He Lured May Want to Stay
item.description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus, whom the E.U. accuses of engineering a migrant crisis on the border with Poland, could face a serious headache if asylum seekers try to stay in his country.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants in Belarus on the border with Poland, which has been girded with razor wire, on Wednesday.

item.title: Vaccinated vs. Unvaccinated: Europe’s Covid Culture War
item.description: In pockets of Europe, vaccine resistance has become the long tail of the populist nationalist movements that shook up European politics for a decade.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times

item.title: Mass Detentions of Civilians Fan ‘Climate of Fear’ in Ethiopia
item.description: An ethnically motivated detention campaign largely targeting Ethiopians of Tigrayan descent threatens to further unravel Africa’s second-most populous country a year into a civil war.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: With police stations full of Tigrayan detainees, the authorities have moved the overflow to makeshift facilities. This agricultural college near the town of Assosa is said to be one of them.

item.title: U.K. Inflation Hits a 10-Year High
item.description: Prices rose 4.2 percent last month from a year earlier, more than double the Bank of England’s target.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: A gasoline station in Lower Kingswood, south of London. Higher prices at the pump contributed to inflation’s reaching a 10-year high in October.

item.title: Greece to Put Aid Workers Who Helped Migrants on Trial on Espionage Charges
item.description: The country’s conservative government is toughening its stance on migration and on groups working with migrants, aligning itself with a hardening climate across Europe.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers directing a raft of migrants off the Greek island of Lesbos in 2016.

item.title: Boris Johnson Battered in Parliament as Scandal Puts Him on Defense
item.description: Reversals and broken promises have eroded his party’s lead in the polls, and the prime minister faces a low-grade mutiny from Conservatives angry over a proposal to limit their options for extra income.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain faces a furor over Conservative Party lawmakers taking lucrative outside work.

item.title: 2 Austrian States, Including Salzburg, to Impose Covid Lockdowns
item.description: The state, along with neighboring Upper Austria, will apply the restrictions to everyone regardless of inoculation status. The moves come in the wake of national rules affecting unvaccinated people.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Police officers checking shoppers’ vaccination status at a store entrance in Vienna on Wednesday.

item.title: Elusive Migrants Leave Haunting Traces in Polish Forests
item.description: The migrants, themselves are elusive, but they leave behind evidence of the lives they left behind, and of their desperate bids to reach the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk

item.title: As Covid Rules Ease, Australian Open Can Play Before a Full House
item.description: The annual Boxing Day cricket test match in Melbourne will also be allowed to take place before a full-capacity crowd.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic after winning the Australian Open men’s singles title in Melbourne in February.

item.title: Germany Moves to Impose New Covid Regulations
item.description: The measures include a rule that only those who are vaccinated, have recovered from an infection or test negative can ride public transit or attend work in person.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Commuting in Berlin this month. Germany reported yet another record in daily new Covid infections on Wednesday.

item.title: How Biden's Spending Bill Will Change Healthcare
item.description: We’re looking at the ways Biden’s social policy bill will change health care.
item.dc:creator: Margot Sanger-Katz
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A doctor examines a 10-year-old patient in Austin, Texas.

item.title: India's Limit on Syringe Exports Hobbles Global Covid Vaccinations
item.description: The South Asian country is a major producer of the type of syringe used for coronavirus inoculations.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers checking syringes at Hindustan Syringes and Medical Devices, one of the world’s largest syringe makers.

item.title: At Summit, U.S., Canada and Mexico Will Address Migration
item.description: After a five-year hiatus, the meeting of North American leaders will also provide a forum to discuss trade disagreements and vaccine sharing.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants waiting to cross into the United States from Mexico in August. President Biden has had to rely on Mexico to control pandemic-fueled migration from Latin America.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Lukashenko’s risky border actions.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children in Belarus on the border with Poland, which has been girded with razor wire, on Wednesday.

item.title: Munich’s Famed Christmas Market is Canceled Again
item.description: Munich’s is the largest German Christmas market to be canceled as the events struggle to survive the country’s fourth virus surge.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: The Christmas market in Munich in 2013. It has been canceled for a second straight year.

item.title: Biden Administration Plans to Expand Covid Vaccine Production
item.description: The Biden administration will spend billions of dollars on a new plan to combat the pandemic, investing in antiviral pills, rapid tests and manufacturing.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Activists have been demanding for months that Mr. Biden do more to scale up global vaccine manufacturing capacity.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Billions for more vaccine equity.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 6-year-old getting his first dose of the Pfizer vaccine in San Francisco.

item.title: Egypt Prepares to Give Leaders Special Powers in Epidemics
item.description: Critics fear that the legislation will be just another avenue the government can use to crack down on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Nada Rashwan
item.media:description: People waiting to receive a Covid-19 vaccine at the Sadat Metro Station in Cairo on Sunday.

item.title: How the Belarus Standoff Is Unlike Recent Migrant Crises
item.description: The images at the Belarus-Poland border look familiar, but this emergency has little in common with previous waves of people from Syria, Myanmar and Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants camping on the Belarusian side of the border on Tuesday night.

item.title: Beyond the Freezing Forest, a Green Light at the Window for Migrants
item.description: An unofficial network of local residents, activists and volunteer medics in Poland has been working to support those who have made it across from Belarus in bitter conditions.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Ancipuk, a resident of Michalowo, Poland, has placed a green light in a window to show migrants that her home is a safe place to ask for help.

item.title: As the pandemic spread, Americans died of drug overdoses in record numbers.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tammy Adams at her home in Horsham, Pa., last April. Adams’s son, David, died in November 2020 from an overdose.

item.title: Raúl Rivero, Disenchanted Poet of the Cuban Revolution, Dies at 75
item.description: A leading journalistic voice who broke with the Castro regime, he gained wide recognition for his protests, was jailed as a dissident and went into exile.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: The poet and journalist Raúl Rivero in 2005. A loyal supporter of the Cuban revolution, he later broke with President Fidel Castro and was jailed as a dissident.

item.title: Doppa, a Central Asian Hat, Guides Quest for Uyghur Roots
item.description: For an Australian woman with roots in Central Asia, a growing awareness of her heritage and the peril her people face all began with an embroidered skullcap.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:credit: Isabella Moore for The New York Times
item.media:description: Subhi Bora, who was born in Sydney, Australia, to a Uyghur mother and Uzbek father, traveled to Uzbekistan in search of a doppa, a traditional hat, as a way to reconnect with her heritage.

item.title: Liverpool Bomber Had Planned for Months, U.K. Police Say
item.description: The authorities named the man they believe to be behind an explosion in a taxi outside a hospital, who was also the only person killed, as Emad Al Swealmeen, 32.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Police officers working at the site of the explosion outside Liverpool Women's Hospital in northwestern England on Wednesday.

item.title: Netherlands Is Maxing Out Its Covid Testing Capacity
item.description: Soaring demand and a shortage of workers have made appointments almost impossible to find.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: A drive-in screening center in Pijnacker, the Netherlands, on Wednesday. Appointments have become very hard to find.

item.title: A Syrian teenager is buried in Poland, and a pair of brothers are rescued from a forest.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ahmed Al Hasan, 19, was buried on Monday in the small Polish village of Bohoniki, on the outskirts of Sokolka, near the border with Belarus.

item.title: Covid Rules for Beijing Olympics Force Injured Athlete to Fly Home on Cargo Plane
item.description: A Polish luger, Mateusz Sochowicz, was told that coronavirus restrictions prevented him from boarding a commercial flight for another two weeks.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: Mateusz Sochowicz competing in Sochi, Russia, last year.

item.title: The E.U. adopts new sanctions against Belarus.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Josep Borrell Fontelles, the E.U. foreign policy chief, at the E.U. headquarters in Brussels on Monday.

item.title: Where Are Young People Most Optimistic? In Poorer Nations.
item.description: More than half of Americans, young and old, say children today will be less economically successful than their parents, a global survey shows.
item.dc:creator: Claire Cain Miller and Alicia Parlapiano
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Gabriela Portilho for The New York Times; Khadija Farah for The New York Times; Ben Roberts for The New York Times; Marie Eriel Hobro for The New York Times; Andri Tambunan for The New York Times; Anastasia Vlasova for The New York Times; Fabeha Monir for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left, Victor Paganotto Carvalho Freitas of Brazil; Lorraine Nduta of Kenya; Angela Bahamonde Ahijado of Spain; Landen Otaka of Hawaii; Makeila Ward of Nevada; Valeriia Drabych of Ukraine; and Md. Rafaiat Ullah of Bangladesh.

item.title: Sudanese Forces Kill 10 Protesting Coup, Medics Report
item.description: The violence is shadowing Secretary of State Antony Blinken’s visit to Africa.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Declan Walsh and Rick Gladstone
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A protester on his way last week to a demonstration against the military takeover in Omdurman, Sudan.

item.title: The Poland Belarus Border Crisis, Explained
item.description: The situation at the Belarus-Poland border is unlike recent immigration crises.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants on the Belarus-Poland border.

item.title: Peloton and Zoom were two of the hot stocks of the pandemic. Now what?
item.dc:creator: Matt Phillips
item.media:description: After years of going to a gym to work out, Cindy Cicchinelli uses her Peloton exercise machine in her Pittsburgh townhouse.

item.title: Blinken says fighting in Ethiopia ‘needs to stop.’
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken meeting on Wednesday in Nairobi with Kenya’s cabinet secretary for foreign affairs, Raychelle Omamo.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: A clash at the Belarusian-Polish border.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants on the Belarusian-Polish border camps on Tuesday night after a day of clashes with Polish authorities.

item.title: U.S. to Buy Enough of Pfizer’s Covid Antiviral Pills for 10 Million People
item.description: The antiviral drugs have helped inspire hope among senior administration officials that the United States will be able to curb the devastating toll from the Delta variant.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Pfizer on Tuesday applied for federal authorization of its Covid-19 pill on an emergency basis.

item.title: U.S. and China Agree to Ease Restrictions on Journalists
item.description: The deal tones down a diplomatic confrontation that led Beijing to expel some American reporters during the last year of the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden met virtually with President Xi Jinping of China on Monday. One day later, the countries announced a deal making it easier for foreign journalists to obtain visas.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: What the Xi-Biden meeting achieved.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: President Joe Biden meets virtually with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the White House on Monday.

item.title: In Gaza, a Contentious Palestinian Professor Calmly Teaches Israeli Poetry
item.description: On social media, Refaat Alareer rages against Israel. In the lecture hall, he studiously analyzes the work of some of its leading poets — and surprises some of his students.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Professor Refaat Alareer lecturing to his undergraduate literature students at the Islamic University in Gaza City.

item.title: Russia Acknowledges Antisatellite Missile Test That Created a Mess in Space
item.description: The test forced astronauts on the International Space Station to briefly take shelter in re-entry capsules.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Astronauts aboard the International Space Station were forced to seek shelter after a test of a Russian antisatellite weapon generated debris.

item.title: Italian Police Break Up Drug Smuggling Ring Tied to Calabria Mob
item.description: Over 100 people were arrested in Italy as members of a mafia ring that smuggled drugs from Latin America and infiltrated businesses in southern and northern Italy.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: A sign pointing to the courtroom in Lamezia Terme, Italy, where defendants linked to the ’Ndrangheta mafia were being tried this year.

item.title: Woman’s Body Recovered From Mudslide in British Columbia as Evacuations Continue
item.description: “It came down faster than the speed of sound,” said a woman who survived the mudslide. Heavy rainfall and overflowing rivers have inundated cities in the Canadian province.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser, Christine Chung and Alyssa Lukpat

item.title: Clarissa Eden, British Countess and Political Influencer, Dies at 101
item.description: The iconoclastic niece of Winston Churchill, she was married to Prime Minister Anthony Eden, who was at the helm during the Suez crisis.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.media:credit: Monty Fresco Jr./Topical Press Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Clarissa Eden and her husband, Prime Minister Anthony Eden, at 10 Downing Street in 1955. “You were perpetually in evening gowns, tremendous evening clothes — tiaras and God knows what, and long gloves that had to be buttoned up,” Ms Eden said.

item.title: Lekki Toll Gate Shooting in Nigeria Was a Massacre, Panel Finds
item.description: The incident in October 2020 could be “equated with a massacre,” a government panel said, refuting the army’s claim that soldiers only fired blanks.
item.dc:creator: Ben Ezeamalu
item.media:description: A tollgate in Lagos, Nigeria, was the site of a deadly protest in October 2020.

item.title: Spain's Basque Region Restricts Gatherings as Cases Rise
item.description: The move contributes to a national debate on whether the country should reintroduce restrictions to prevent a Covid resurgence this winter.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: A sunny day at Zurriola beach in the Basque region of northern Spain last month.

item.title: Revising China's History, to Glorify Xi Jinping
item.description: The Communist Party has anointed him one of its revered leaders, paving the way for an already powerful leader to wield even greater influence.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China in Beijing last month. The implications of the Communist Party’s jargon-riddled speeches and documents can sometimes be elusive. Not this time.

item.title: Cold and Marooned in a Police State as Desperation Takes Hold
item.description: Almost a dozen migrants have died in recent weeks in the standoff between Belarus, a close ally of Russia, and Poland, a member of NATO and the European Union, each determined not to bend.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins and Marc Santora
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: Who’s to Blame for Rising Prices
item.description: Why do so many things seem to cost more now?
item.dc:creator: Neil Irwin
item.media:description: Gas prices last week in San Diego.

item.title: What Did the US-China Summit Achieve?
item.description: In a chilly relationship of mutual mistrust, staving off the prospect of a broader conflict between two superpowers counts as progress.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and David E. Sanger

item.title: Will Indonesia Edge Its Way into the Space Race?
item.description: An Indigenous clan fears it will lose its place in the world as the government pursues a quest to open a spaceport and lure the billionaire SpaceX founder Elon Musk.
item.dc:creator: Dera Menra Sijabat, Richard C. Paddock and Ulet Ifansasti

item.title: Cities Are Not Only Tackling Covid, But Its Pollution, Too
item.description: All around the world the remnants of a global pandemic are testing the resolve of governments and private firms to rid the planet of its waste.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Leigh Hester
item.media:description: Gary Stokes, founder of the environmental group Oceans Asia, displays discarded face masks found on a beach on the outlying Lantau island in Hong Kong.

item.title: Zalmay Khalilzad Battles Critics in U.S. and Afghanistan
item.description: Zalmay Khalilzad, who stepped down as the envoy for Afghanistan after the U.S. exit, has defended the deal he negotiated with the Taliban during the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zalmay Khalilzad is defending his reputation against charges that he bears special blame for the chaotic fall of Kabul, the Afghan capital, to the Taliban in August.
